ground_truth: Mozart is suddenly delighted and throws the door wide open so that the guests can see into the private apartment where the Archbishop sits, and he can see them. Colloredo is clearly discomfited by this reception of his employee, smiling and bowing uneasily as they include him in the small ovation. Mozart stands in the corridor, out of the Archbishop's line of sight, bowing and giggling, and encouraging the applause for the Archbishop with conducting gestures. Suddenly irritated, Colloredo signs to Arco, who steps forward and shuts the door, ending the applause. Salieri, in this vast room, is standing and looking at the full score of the Serenade. Instantly, we again hear its lyrical strains. Salieri reads the score of the Adagio in helpless fascination, but suddenly the music snaps off as Mozart stands before him and lays down the score. Mozart takes the score, bows, and struts briskly out of the room, while Salieri stares uncomprehendingly after the jaunty little figure. At a table sits Emperor Joseph II, eating his frugal dinner and sipping goat's milk. He is an intelligent, dapper man of forty, wearing a military uniform, surrounded by his Chamberlain Johann Von Strack, Count Orsini-Rosenberg, Baron Von Swieten, First Kapellmeister Giuseppe Bonno, and Salieri, who wears decorous black as usual. At a side-table, two Imperial secretaries use quill pens and inkstands to write down everything of importance that is said. Salieri looks defiantly at Orsini-Rosenberg. In a somber room which serves as both a bedroom and a study, opposite an image sits Salieri at his desk, on which stands a pile of music paper, quill pens, and ink. He occasionally tries notes from the march he is composing on an open forte-piano with some difficulty, scratching notes out with his quill and ruffling his hair without a powdered wig. The Salesman puts the second wig on Mozart's head, who pulls a face of doubt in the mirror and giggles. Mozart turns and comes into the salon, where another group awaits him, consisting of Von Strack, Orsini-Rosenberg, Bonno, Von Swieten, and Salieri in a room containing several gilded chairs and a forte-piano. All bow and say, "Good morning, Your Majesty." The Emperor produces a paper, goes to the instrument, sits, and plays the first bars of it, but plays a wrong note. Mozart throws himself to his knees and, to Joseph's discomfort, kisses the royal hand with fervour.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: Mozart is abruptly pleased and flings the portal wide open so that the visitors can perceive into the private chamber where the Archbishop resides, and he can perceive them. Colloredo is plainly unsettled by this welcome of his worker, grinning and inclining uncomfortably as they involve him in the small tribute. Mozart stands in the passage, out of the Archbishop's field of vision, inclining and chuckling, and fostering the acclamation for the Archbishop with directing motions. Abruptly annoyed, Colloredo signals to Arco, who advances and closes the portal, terminating the acclamation. Salieri, in this enormous space, is standing and gazing at the full score of the Serenade. Immediately, we again hear its melodious strains. Salieri scrutinizes the score of the Adagio in powerless captivation, but abruptly the music cuts off as Mozart stands before him and sets down the score. Mozart takes the score, bows, and strides swiftly out of the space, while Salieri gazes unintelligibly after the lively little figure. At a table sits Emperor Joseph II, consuming his meager meal and sipping goat's milk. He is a perceptive, neat man of forty, wearing a martial attire, encircled by his Chamberlain Johann Von Strack, Count Orsini-Rosenberg, Baron Von Swieten, First Kapellmeister Giuseppe Bonno, and Salieri, who wears proper black as typical. At a side-table, two Imperial secretaries employ quill pens and inkwells to transcribe everything of significance that is uttered. Salieri glances defiantly at Orsini-Rosenberg. In a gloomy space which serves as both a bedroom and a study, opposite an image sits Salieri at his desk, on which stands a stack of music paper, quill pens, and ink. He occasionally tries notes from the march he is composing on an open forte-piano with some difficulty, scratching notes out with his quill and ruffling his hair without a powdered wig. The Salesman places the second wig on Mozart's head, who pulls a face of uncertainty in the mirror and giggles. Mozart turns and enters the salon, where another assembly awaits him, comprising Von Strack, Orsini-Rosenberg, Bonno, Von Swieten, and Salieri in a chamber containing several gilded chairs and a forte-piano. All bow and say, "Good morning, Your Majesty." The Emperor produces a paper, goes to the instrument, sits, and plays the initial bars of it, but plays an incorrect note. Mozart hurls himself to his knees and, to Joseph's discomfort, kisses the royal hand with zeal.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: Mozart is suddenly delighted, and the door is thrown wide open by him so that the guests can see into the private apartment where the Archbishop sits, and he can see them. This reception of his employee clearly discomfits Colloredo, who smiles and bows uneasily as they include him in the small ovation. The corridor is stood in by Mozart, out of the Archbishop's line of sight, bowing and giggling, and the applause for the Archbishop is encouraged by him with conducting gestures. Suddenly irritated, Arco is signed to by Colloredo, who steps forward and shuts the door, ending the applause. In this vast room, Salieri stands and looks at the full score of the Serenade. Instantly, its lyrical strains are again heard by us. The score of the Adagio is read by Salieri in helpless fascination, but suddenly the music snaps off as the score is laid down before him by Mozart. The score is taken by Mozart, who bows and struts briskly out of the room, while Salieri stares uncomprehendingly after the jaunty little figure. At a table, Emperor Joseph II sits, eating his frugal dinner and sipping goat's milk. He is an intelligent, dapper man of forty, wearing a military uniform, and he is surrounded by his Chamberlain Johann Von Strack, Count Orsini-Rosenberg, Baron Von Swieten, First Kapellmeister Giuseppe Bonno, and Salieri, who wears decorous black as usual. At a side table, quill pens and inkstands are used by two Imperial secretaries to write down everything of importance that is said. Orsini-Rosenberg is looked at defiantly by Salieri. In a somber room which serves as both a bedroom and a study, opposite an image Salieri sits at his desk, on which stands a pile of music paper, quill pens, and ink. Notes from the march he is composing are occasionally tried by him on an open forte-piano with some difficulty, and notes are scratched out with his quill, and his hair is ruffled without a powdered wig. The second wig is put on Mozart's head by the Salesman, who pulls a face of doubt in the mirror and giggles. Mozart turns and comes into the salon, where he is awaited by another group, consisting of Von Strack, Orsini-Rosenberg, Bonno, Von Swieten, and Salieri in a room containing several gilded chairs and a forte-piano. All bow and say, "Good morning, Your Majesty." A paper is produced by the Emperor, who goes to the instrument, sits, and plays the first bars of it, but a wrong note is played by him. To Joseph's discomfort, Mozart throws himself to his knees and kisses the royal hand with fervor.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Mozart joyfully opens the door to reveal the Archbishop's private apartment, prompting an uneasy smile and bow from Colloredo as he is included in the guests' applause. Hidden from Colloredo's view, Mozart amplifies the applause with gestures until Arco shuts the door, ending it. In the expansive room, Salieri reads the Serenade's full score, captivated by the Adagio, until the music stops as Mozart takes the score and exits, leaving Salieri puzzled. Emperor Joseph II, a sharp, well-dressed forty-year-old in military garb, dines modestly with goat's milk, accompanied by Chamberlain Johann Von Strack, Count Orsini-Rosenberg, Baron Von Swieten, First Kapellmeister Giuseppe Bonno, and Salieri in his usual black. Two secretaries use quills to record significant conversations. Salieri defiantly eyes Orsini-Rosenberg. In a dual-purpose bedroom and study, Salieri struggles with composing on a forte-piano, correcting notes and ruffling his hair. Meanwhile, a salesman fits Mozart with a second wig, causing Mozart to make a doubtful face and giggle. Mozart enters a salon where Von Strack, Orsini-Rosenberg, Bonno, Von Swieten, and Salieri await in a room with gilded chairs and a forte-piano. The group bows, greeting the Emperor with "Good morning, Your Majesty." The Emperor plays the first bars of a piece, erring on a note, prompting Mozart to enthusiastically kneel and kiss the Emperor's hand, causing Joseph discomfort.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Mozart, suddenly delighted, throws the door open, revealing the Archbishop to guests. Colloredo, uneasy, smiles and bows as he is included in the ovation. Mozart stands in the corridor, out of view, encouraging applause with gestures. Annoyed, Colloredo signals Arco to close the door, ending the applause. In a large room, Salieri stands, fascinated by the Serenade score, but as Mozart approaches and lays down the score, the music stops. Mozart bows and leaves, while Salieri watches. Emperor Joseph II, eating dinner in military uniform, is surrounded by Chamberlain Johann Von Strack, Count Orsini-Rosenberg, Baron Von Swieten, Kapellmeister Bonno, and Salieri in black. Two secretaries record important discussions. Defiantly, Salieri looks at Orsini-Rosenberg. In his somber bedroom-study, Salieri struggles to compose a march, scratching out notes on paper, ruffling his hair. A Salesman places a wig on Mozart, who doubts in the mirror but giggles. Mozart enters the salon to Von Strack, Orsini-Rosenberg, Bonno, Von Swieten, and Salieri, who bow, greeting, "Good morning, Your Majesty." The Emperor sits at an instrument, playing a sheet's first bars but hits a wrong note. Mozart kneels and fervently kisses Joseph's hand, causing discomfort.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description:
Mozart is suddenly filled with an overwhelming sense of delight and, in a burst of energy, throws the door wide open. He does this so that the guests gathered can have a clear view into the private apartment where the Archbishop is seated, and equally, so that the Archbishop can also see them. Colloredo, clearly discomfited by this unexpected reception of his employee, smiles and bows uneasily as he finds himself included in the small ovation. Meanwhile, Mozart remains standing in the corridor, strategically out of the Archbishop's line of sight, bowing and giggling with evident amusement. He enthusiastically encourages the applause for the Archbishop by making conducting gestures. Suddenly becoming irritated, Colloredo signals to Arco, who promptly steps forward and shuts the door, effectively bringing the applause to an end. 

In this vast, echoing room, Salieri stands absorbed, looking at the full score of the Serenade with keen interest. Instantly, we are transported into the world of music as we hear its lyrical strains playing beautifully. Salieri reads through the score of the Adagio with helpless fascination, captivated by its brilliance, but suddenly the music comes to an abrupt halt as Mozart appears before him and lays the score down. With a flourish, Mozart takes the score, bows theatrically, and struts briskly out of the room, leaving Salieri staring uncomprehendingly after the jaunty little figure that is now retreating.

Seated at a table is Emperor Joseph II, partaking in his frugal dinner and sipping modestly on goat's milk. He is an intelligent and dapper man of about forty years, dressed smartly in a military uniform. He is surrounded by his Chamberlain Johann Von Strack, Count Orsini-Rosenberg, Baron Von Swieten, First Kapellmeister Giuseppe Bonno, and Salieri, who is attired in his usual decorous black garments. At a side-table, two Imperial secretaries diligently use quill pens and inkstands to meticulously write down everything of importance that is being said. Salieri looks defiantly at Orsini-Rosenberg, clear in his stance.

In a somber room which serves the dual purpose of a bedroom and a study, Salieri sits at his desk, opposite an image, with a pile of music paper, quill pens, and ink arranged before him. He occasionally attempts notes from the march he is composing on an open forte-piano, finding it somewhat challenging. He scratches out notes with his quill and ruffles his hair, which is without a powdered wig, as he tries to piece the music together. Meanwhile, the Salesman places the second wig on Mozart's head, prompting Mozart to pull a face of doubt in the mirror, followed by a bout of giggles.

Mozart turns and enters the salon, where another group awaits him eagerly. This group is composed of Von Strack, Orsini-Rosenberg, Bonno, Von Swieten, and Salieri, all gathered in a room filled with several gilded chairs and a prominently placed forte-piano. They all bow gracefully and say in unison, "Good morning, Your Majesty." The Emperor, producing a paper, moves to the instrument, sits down, and plays the first bars of what is written, although he inadvertently plays a wrong note. Mozart, in a dramatic gesture, throws himself to his knees and, much to Joseph's discomfort, kisses the royal hand with fervor and admiration.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
Mozart, suddenly overtaken by an intense and overwhelming sense of sheer delight, finds himself bursting with energy. With this newfound vigor, he dramatically flings the door wide open with a flourish. He does this to ensure that all the guests who have gathered can have an unobstructed view into the private and somewhat secluded apartment where the Archbishop sits. Similarly, he wants to make certain that the Archbishop can see the guests as well. Colloredo, clearly flustered and discomfited by this unexpected and somewhat unconventional reception from his employee, forces a smile and bows somewhat uneasily as he finds himself unexpectedly acknowledged in the small ovation. Meanwhile, Mozart chooses to remain standing strategically in the corridor, just out of the Archbishop's direct line of sight. He is bowing and giggling with evident, almost childlike amusement. Encouraging the applause for the Archbishop with great enthusiasm, he makes conducting gestures. Suddenly, Colloredo becomes irritated and signals to Arco, who quickly steps forward to shut the door, effectively bringing the applause to a sudden end.

In this vast and echoing room, Salieri stands absorbed, engrossed in the full score of the Serenade, examining it with keen and focused interest. Instantly, we are metaphorically transported into the enchanting world of music, as we hear the lyrical strains playing beautifully around us. Salieri delves into the score of the Adagio with a sense of helpless fascination, utterly captivated by its brilliance. However, the music abruptly comes to a halt as Mozart suddenly appears before him and lays the score down with a flourish. With theatrical flair, Mozart takes the score, bows dramatically, and then briskly struts out of the room, leaving Salieri behind, staring uncomprehendingly after the jaunty little figure that is now retreating.

Seated comfortably at a table is Emperor Joseph II, who is partaking in a frugal and modest dinner, discreetly sipping on goat's milk. He is an intelligent and dapper gentleman of about forty years, dressed smartly in a sharply tailored military uniform. He is accompanied by his Chamberlain Johann Von Strack, Count Orsini-Rosenberg, Baron Von Swieten, First Kapellmeister Giuseppe Bonno, and Salieri himself, who is attired in his usual decorous black garments. At a side table, two Imperial secretaries are diligently using quill pens and inkstands to meticulously write down every piece of important discourse being uttered. Salieri looks defiantly at Orsini-Rosenberg, clear and resolute in his stance.

In a somber room serving the dual purpose of a bedroom and a study, Salieri sits at his desk, opposite an image, with a neat pile of music paper, quill pens, and ink carefully arranged before him. He occasionally attempts to play notes from the march he is in the process of composing on an open forte-piano, finding the task to be somewhat challenging. He scratches out notes with his quill, ruffling his hair, which is bereft of a powdered wig, as he tries to piece the music together. Meanwhile, the Salesman places a second, more elaborate wig on Mozart's head, prompting Mozart to pull a doubtful face when looking in the mirror, followed by a bout of giggles.

Mozart turns and enters the salon, where yet another eager group awaits him. This group is composed of Von Strack, Orsini-Rosenberg, Bonno, Von Swieten, and Salieri, gathered in a room filled with several gilded chairs and a prominently placed forte-piano. They all bow gracefully, united in a harmonious chorus, and say, "Good morning, Your Majesty." The Emperor, producing a paper with a flourish, moves confidently to the instrument, sits down, and plays the first bars of what is written, although he inadvertently strikes a wrong note. In a dramatic and almost theatrical gesture, Mozart throws himself to his knees and, much to Emperor Joseph's discomfort, kisses the royal hand with fervor and deep admiration.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Mozart experiences a sudden burst of delight and energetically flings the door open wide so that the guests standing outside can have a clear view into the private apartment where the Archbishop is seated, and simultaneously, the Archbishop can see the guests. The sudden exposure causes Colloredo to feel visibly uncomfortable with the unexpected reception of his employee, prompting him to smile awkwardly and bow uneasily as he is included in the small ovation initiated by those present. Meanwhile, Mozart strategically positions himself in the corridor, ensuring he remains out of the Archbishop's line of sight, and starts bowing and giggling with a playful demeanor. He enthusiastically encourages the ongoing applause directed at the Archbishop by making conducting gestures. However, the atmosphere changes quickly when Colloredo, now irritated by the proceedings, signals to Arco, who promptly steps forward to close the door, bringing the applause to an abrupt halt. In a different, spacious room, Salieri stands absorbed in examining the full score of the Serenade, during which the lyrical strains of the music vividly fill the air. As he reads the score of the Adagio, Salieri becomes enraptured, studying it with helpless fascination, until suddenly, the music cuts off sharply as Mozart appears before him, gently placing the score down. With a swift movement, Mozart retrieves the score, executes a polite bow, and then struts briskly out of the room, leaving Salieri to gaze, uncomprehendingly, at his jaunty departure. Meanwhile, Emperor Joseph II, an intelligent and dapper man of forty dressed in a military uniform, is at a table enjoying his simple meal of frugal dinner paired with sips of goat's milk. He is surrounded by his Chamberlain Johann Von Strack, Count Orsini-Rosenberg, Baron Von Swieten, First Kapellmeister Giuseppe Bonno, and Salieri, who is characteristically dressed in decorous black. At an adjacent side-table, two Imperial secretaries are diligently recording everything of significance being said, utilizing quill pens and inkstands for their task. Salieri casts a defiant look at Orsini-Rosenberg. In a somber room that doubles as both a bedroom and a study, Salieri sits at his desk, across from an image, with a pile of music paper, quill pens, and ink laid out before him. He occasionally attempts notes from the march he is attempting to compose on an open forte-piano, struggling somewhat, intermittently scratching notes out with his quill and ruffling his hair, notably untamed without a powdered wig. Meanwhile, a salesman places a second wig onto Mozart's head, prompting Mozart to make a doubtful face at his reflection in the mirror before letting out a giggle. Mozart then turns away from his reflection and enters the salon, where another group is eagerly awaiting him. This group comprises Von Strack, Orsini-Rosenberg, Bonno, Von Swieten, and Salieri, all gathered in a room furnished with several gilded chairs and a forte-piano. They collectively bow and greet the Emperor with, "Good morning, Your Majesty." In response, the Emperor produces a piece of paper, approaches the instrument, takes a seat, and begins to play the first few bars from it, only to falter by playing a wrong note. Reacting with dramatic fervor, Mozart throws himself to his knees and, to the clear discomfort of Joseph, ardently kisses the royal hand.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: Mozart joyfully flings open the door to reveal the Archbishop to the guests, prompting an uneasy but polite acknowledgment from Colloredo as he's drawn into the applause. As Mozart remains hidden from view, he encourages the applause with playful conducting gestures until an irked Colloredo signals Arco to shut the door, silencing the ovation. Meanwhile, Salieri stands in a large room, absorbed in the Serenade's score, entranced by the Adagio until Mozart arrives, ends the music by laying down the score, and briskly exits, leaving Salieri puzzled. In another scene, Emperor Joseph II, an intelligent and dapper man, eats a simple meal while surrounded by his court, including Salieri in his customary black. Nearby, two secretaries diligently record important conversations. Salieri exchanges a defiant look with Orsini-Rosenberg. Later, in a somber dual-purpose room, Salieri struggles with his composition at the forte-piano, scratching out notes in frustration. Meanwhile, a Salesman fits Mozart with a wig, causing him to giggle at his reflection before joining a waiting group of dignitaries, including Salieri, in a salon. Upon greeting Emperor Joseph II, who attempts to play a piece but hits a wrong note, Mozart drops to his knees and fervently kisses the Emperor's hand, much to the latter's discomfort.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: Mozart, the celebrated composer and musical prodigy of the 18th century, is suddenly delighted and throws the door wide open so that the guests can see into the private apartment where the Archbishop Colloredo, the Prince-Archbishop of Salzburg and Mozart's employer, sits, and he can see them. Colloredo is clearly discomfited by this reception of his employee, smiling and bowing uneasily as they include him in the small ovation, which reflects Mozart's growing fame and contentious relationship with his patron. Mozart stands in the corridor, out of the Archbishop's line of sight, bowing and giggling, and encouraging the applause for the Archbishop with conducting gestures that highlight his irreverent humor and charm. Suddenly irritated, Colloredo signs to Arco, his aide, who steps forward and shuts the door, ending the applause. Salieri, in this vast room filled with opulent decor typical of the period's aristocratic residences, is standing and looking at the full score of the Serenade, a form of music designed to entertain. Instantly, we again hear its lyrical strains, showcasing Mozart's genius in crafting melodies. Salieri reads the score of the Adagio in helpless fascination, but suddenly the music snaps off as Mozart stands before him and lays down the score, an action symbolizing both his dominance and playful nature. Mozart takes the score, bows, and struts briskly out of the room, while Salieri stares uncomprehendingly after the jaunty little figure, emblematic of his rival's mysterious brilliance. At a table sits Emperor Joseph II, the reform-minded ruler of the Holy Roman Empire who patronized the arts, eating his frugal dinner and sipping goat's milk, a nod to his personal asceticism and preference for simple living. He is an intelligent, dapper man of forty, wearing a military uniform, symbolizing his role as both a statesman and military leader, surrounded by his Chamberlain Johann Von Strack, Count Orsini-Rosenberg, Baron Von Swieten, First Kapellmeister Giuseppe Bonno, and Salieri, who wears decorous black as usual, reflecting the fashion of court musicians of the time. At a side-table, two Imperial secretaries use quill pens and inkstands, tools of the trade in the pre-industrial age, to write down everything of importance that is said. Salieri looks defiantly at Orsini-Rosenberg, a significant figure in the court's music administration. In a somber room which serves as both a bedroom and a study, typical of 18th-century accommodations for individuals of modest means, opposite an image sits Salieri at his desk, on which stands a pile of music paper, quill pens, and ink, essential for the manual composition of music. He occasionally tries notes from the march he is composing on an open forte-piano, a precursor to the modern piano, with some difficulty, scratching notes out with his quill and ruffling his hair without a powdered wig, which was fashionable but often uncomfortable. The Salesman puts the second wig on Mozart's head, who pulls a face of doubt in the mirror and giggles, an expression of his playful personality. Mozart turns and comes into the salon, where another group awaits him, consisting of Von Strack, Orsini-Rosenberg, Bonno, Von Swieten, and Salieri in a room containing several gilded chairs, indicative of the era's opulent furnishings, and a forte-piano. All bow and say, "Good morning, Your Majesty," to the Emperor, acknowledging his presence with the courtly etiquette of the time. The Emperor produces a paper, goes to the instrument, sits, and plays the first bars of it, but plays a wrong note, an endearing humanizing moment for the ruler. Mozart throws himself to his knees and, to Joseph's discomfort, kisses the royal hand with fervour, a gesture of exaggerated deference that underscores his theatrical nature.

Colloredo is clearly discomfited by this reception of his employee smiling and bowing uneasily as they include him in the small ovation. Mozart stands in the corridor out of the Archbishop's line of sight bowing and giggling and encouraging the applause for the Archbishop with conducting gestures. Suddenly irritated Colloredo signs to Arco who steps forward and shuts the door ending the applause. Salieri in this vast room is standing and looking at the full score of the Serenade. Instantly we again hear its lyrical strains. Salieri reads the score of the Adagio in helpless fascination but suddenly the music snaps off as Mozart stands before him and lays down the score. Mozart takes the score bows and struts briskly out of the room while Salieri stares uncomprehendingly after the jaunty little figure. At a table sits Emperor Joseph II eating his frugal dinner and sipping goat's milk. He is an intelligent dapper man of forty wearing a military uniform surrounded by his Chamberlain Johann Von Strack Count OrsiniRosenberg Baron Von Swieten. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. At a sidetable two Imperial secretaries use quill pens and inkstands to write down everything of importance that is said. Salieri looks defiantly at OrsiniRosenberg. In a somber room which serves as both a bedroom and a study. opposite an image sits Salieri at his desk on which stands a pile of music paper quill pens and ink. He occasionally tries notes from the march he is composing on an open fortepiano with some difficulty scratching notes out with his quill and ruffling his hair without a powdered wig. The Salesman puts the second wig on Mozart's head who pulls a face of doubt in the mirror and giggles. Mozart turns and comes into the salon where another group awaits him consisting of Von Strack OrsiniRosenberg Bonno Von Swieten and Salieri in a room containing several gilded chairs and a fortepiano. All bow and say Good morning Your Majesty. The Emperor produces a paper goes to the instrument sits and plays the first bars of it but plays a wrong note. Mozart throws himself to his knees and to Joseph's discomfort kisses the royal hand with fervour.

test_cases.name: Addition (~80%)
test_cases.description: Mozart is suddenly delighted and throws the door wide open so that the guests can see into the private apartment where the Archbishop sits and he can see them. Colloredo is clearly discomfited by this reception of his employee smiling and bowing uneasily as they include him in the small ovation. Mozart stands in the corridor out of the Archbishop's line of sight bowing and giggling and encouraging the applause for the Archbishop with conducting gestures. Suddenly irritated Colloredo signs to Arco who steps forward and shuts the door ending the applause. Salieri in this vast room is standing and looking at the full score of the Serenade. Instantly we again hear its lyrical strains. Salieri reads the score of the Adagio in helpless fascination but suddenly the music snaps off as Mozart stands before him and lays down the score. Mozart takes the score bows and struts briskly out of the room while Salieri stares uncomprehendingly after the jaunty little figure. At a table sits Emperor Joseph II eating his frugal dinner and sipping goat's milk. He is an intelligent dapper man of forty wearing a military uniform surrounded by his Chamberlain Johann Von Strack Count OrsiniRosenberg Baron Von Swieten. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. First Kapellmeister Giuseppe Bonno and Salieri who wears decorous black as usual. At a sidetable two Imperial secretaries use quill pens and inkstands to write down everything of importance that is said. Salieri looks defiantly at OrsiniRosenberg. In a somber room which serves as both a bedroom and a study. opposite an image sits Salieri at his desk on which stands a pile of music paper quill pens and ink. He occasionally tries notes from the march he is composing on an open fortepiano with some difficulty scratching notes out with his quill and ruffling his hair without a powdered wig. All bow and say Good morning Your Majesty. The Emperor produces a paper goes to the instrument sits and plays the first bars of it but plays a wrong note. Mozart throws himself to his knees and to Joseph's discomfort kisses the royal hand with fervour.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~80%)
test_cases.description: Mozart is suddenly delighted and throws the door wide open so that the guests can see into the private apartment where the Archbishop sits and he can see them. Colloredo is clearly discomfited by this reception of his employee smiling and bowing uneasily as they include him in the small ovation. All bow and say Good morning Your Majesty. The Emperor produces a paper goes to the instrument sits and plays the first bars of it but plays a wrong note. Mozart throws himself to his knees and to Joseph's discomfort kisses the royal hand with fervour.

test_cases.name: Subject Corruption
test_cases.description: Beethoven is suddenly delighted and throws the door wide open so that the guests can see into the private apartment where the Duke sits, and he can see them. Così Fan Tutte is clearly discomfited by this reception of his employee, smiling and bowing uneasily as they include him in the small ovation. Beethoven stands in the corridor, out of the Duke's line of sight, bowing and giggling, and encouraging the applause for the Duke with conducting gestures. Suddenly irritated, Così Fan Tutte signs to Chopin, who steps forward and shuts the door, ending the applause. Wagner, in this vast room, is standing and looking at the full score of the Serenade. Instantly, we again hear its lyrical strains. Wagner reads the score of the Adagio in helpless fascination, but suddenly the music snaps off as Beethoven stands before him and lays down the score. Beethoven takes the score, bows, and struts briskly out of the room, while Wagner stares uncomprehendingly after the jaunty little figure. At a table sits King Ludwig II, eating his frugal dinner and sipping goat's milk. He is an intelligent, dapper man of forty, wearing a military uniform, surrounded by his Chamberlain Franz Liszt, Count Mephistopheles, Baron J.S. Bach, First Kapellmeister Claude Debussy, and Wagner, who wears decorous black as usual. At a side-table, two Imperial secretaries use quill pens and inkstands to write down everything of importance that is said. Wagner looks defiantly at Mephistopheles. In a somber room which serves as both a bedroom and a study, opposite an image sits Wagner at his desk, on which stands a pile of music paper, quill pens, and ink. He occasionally tries notes from the march he is composing on an open forte-piano with some difficulty, scratching notes out with his quill and ruffling his hair without a powdered wig. The Blacksmith puts the second wig on Beethoven's head, who pulls a face of doubt in the mirror and giggles. Beethoven turns and comes into the salon, where another group awaits him, consisting of Liszt, Mephistopheles, Debussy, Bach, and Wagner in a room containing several gilded chairs and a forte-piano. All bow and say, "Good morning, Your Highness." The King produces a paper, goes to the instrument, sits, and plays the first bars of it, but plays a wrong note. Beethoven throws himself to his knees and, to Ludwig's discomfort, kisses the royal hand with fervour.

test_cases.name: Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Mozart is suddenly delighted and throws the window wide open so that the guests can see into the private greenhouse where the Archbishop sits, and he can see them. Colloredo is clearly discomfited by this reception of his employee, smiling and bowing uneasily as they include him in the small ovation. Mozart stands in the hallway, out of the Archbishop's line of sight, bowing and giggling, and encouraging the applause for the Archbishop with conducting gestures. Suddenly irritated, Colloredo signs to Arco, who steps forward and closes the curtain, ending the applause. Salieri, in this vast garden, is standing and looking at the full map of the Serenade. Instantly, we again hear its lyrical strains. Salieri reads the map of the Adagio in helpless fascination, but suddenly the music snaps off as Mozart stands before him and lays down the map. Mozart takes the map, bows, and struts briskly out of the greenhouse, while Salieri stares uncomprehendingly after the jaunty little figure. At a beach sits Emperor Joseph II, eating his frugal salad and sipping almond milk. He is an intelligent, dapper man of forty, wearing a sailor uniform, surrounded by his Chamberlain Johann Von Strack, Count Orsini-Rosenberg, Baron Von Swieten, First Navigator Giuseppe Bonno, and Salieri, who wears decorous blue as usual. At a side-stand, two Imperial assistants use fountain pens and notebooks to write down everything of importance that is said. Salieri looks defiantly at Orsini-Rosenberg. In a somber office which serves as both a dining room and a study, opposite a painting sits Salieri at his desk, on which stands a pile of poetry paper, fountain pens, and ink. He occasionally tries notes from the march he is composing on an open guitar with some difficulty, scratching notes out with his fountain pen and ruffling his hair without a straw hat. The Salesman puts the second hat on Mozart's head, who pulls a face of doubt in the mirror and giggles. Mozart turns and comes into the courtyard, where another group awaits him, consisting of Von Strack, Orsini-Rosenberg, Bonno, Von Swieten, and Salieri in a space containing several silver stools and a guitar. All bow and say, "Good afternoon, Your Excellency." The Emperor produces a scroll, goes to the drum, sits, and plays the first bars of it, but plays a wrong note. Mozart throws himself to his knees and, to Joseph's discomfort, kisses the royal shoe with fervour.

test_cases.name: Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Mozart is suddenly amused and flings the door slightly ajar so that the guests can peek into the private apartment where the Archbishop naps, and he can admire them. Colloredo is clearly unsettled by this introduction of his employee, chuckling and nodding awkwardly as they exclude him from the small tribute. Mozart leans in the corridor, out of the Archbishop's line of sight, nodding and snickering, and discouraging the applause for the Archbishop with clapping gestures. Suddenly perturbed, Colloredo waves to Arco, who approaches and opens the door, commencing the silence. Salieri, in this expansive room, is reclining and gazing at the full score of the Serenade. Instantly, we again see its lyrical notations. Salieri skims the score of the Adagio in helpless obsession, but suddenly the music fades away as Mozart skips before him and lifts up the score. Mozart grips the score, nods, and sashays calmly out of the room, while Salieri glares confusedly after the confident little figure. At a table sits Emperor Joseph II, preparing his frugal dinner and tasting goat's milk. He is an astute, elegant man of forty, donning a military uniform, accompanied by his Chamberlain Johann Von Strack, Count Orsini-Rosenberg, Baron Von Swieten, First Kapellmeister Giuseppe Bonno, and Salieri, who wears modest black as usual. At a side-table, two Imperial secretaries use quill pens and inkstands to erase everything of importance that is said. Salieri glances confidently at Orsini-Rosenberg. In a somber room which serves as both a bedroom and a study, opposite an image stands Salieri at his desk, on which lies a pile of music paper, quill pens, and ink. He occasionally forgets notes from the march he is composing on an open forte-piano with some ease, adding notes with his quill and smoothing his hair without a powdered wig. The Salesman removes the second wig from Mozart's head, who pulls a face of delight in the mirror and chuckles. Mozart spins and hides into the salon, where another group evades him, consisting of Von Strack, Orsini-Rosenberg, Bonno, Von Swieten, and Salieri in a room containing several tarnished chairs and a forte-piano. All stand and say, "Good evening, Your Majesty." The Emperor discards a paper, goes to the instrument, stands, and strums the first bars of it, but plays a right note. Mozart elevates himself to his knees and, to Joseph's discomfort, shakes the royal hand with zeal.

test_cases.name: Subject-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Picasso is suddenly delighted and throws the window wide open so that the dancers can see into the secret garden where the Baker sits, and he can see them. Michelangelo is clearly discomfited by this reception of his gardener, smiling and bowing uneasily as they include him in the small ovation. Picasso stands in the garage, out of the Baker's line of sight, bowing and giggling, and encouraging the applause for the Baker with conducting gestures. Suddenly irritated, Michelangelo signs to Escoffier, who steps forward and shuts the window, ending the applause. Monet, in this vast theater, is standing and looking at the full menu of the Banquet. Instantly, we again hear its lyrical strains. Monet reads the menu of the Dessert in helpless fascination, but suddenly the music snaps off as Picasso stands before him and lays down the menu. Picasso takes the menu, bows, and struts briskly out of the theater, while Monet stares uncomprehendingly after the jaunty little figure. At a bench sits King Louis XIV, eating his frugal breakfast and sipping squirrel's milk. He is an intelligent, dapper woman of sixty, wearing a sailor uniform, surrounded by his Gardener Pierre, Duke Van Helsing, Lady Van Plaatsen, First Conductor Lorenzo Vivaldi, and Monet, who wears decorous blue as usual. At a side-bench, two Royal scribes use paintbrushes and palettes to paint down everything of importance that is said. Monet looks defiantly at Van Helsing. In a somber studio which serves as both a craft room and a library, opposite an sculpture sits Monet at his easel, on which stands a pile of canvas, paintbrushes, and pastels. He occasionally tries strokes from the landscape he is painting on an open easel with some difficulty, scratching strokes out with his brush and ruffling his hair without a feathered hat. The Gardener puts the second hat on Picasso's head, who pulls a face of doubt in the fountain and giggles. Picasso turns and comes into the gallery, where another group awaits him, consisting of Pierre, Van Helsing, Vivaldi, Lady Van Plaatsen, and Monet in a garden containing several marble benches and a lyre. All bow and say, "Good morning, Your Highness." The King produces a canvas, goes to the easel, sits, and paints the first strokes of it, but paints a wrong stroke. Picasso throws himself to his knees and, to Louis's discomfort, kisses the royal foot with fervour.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Bach is suddenly amused and flings the window wide open so that the spectators can see into the private gallery where the Queen lounges, and she can see them. Leopold is clearly unnerved by this unveiling of his associate, grinning and nodding awkwardly as they envelop him in the modest applause. Bach stands in the hallway, out of the Queen's line of vision, nodding and chuckling, and fostering the cheer for the Queen with waving gestures. Suddenly vexed, Leopold gestures to Gustav, who strides forward and closes the window, silencing the cheer. Beethoven, in this grand chamber, is sitting and examining the full score of the Concerto. Instantly, we again hear its harmonious chords. Beethoven scans the score of the Allegro in powerless wonder, but suddenly the sound cuts off as Bach stands before him and sets down the score. Bach takes the score, nods, and strides jauntily out of the chamber, while Beethoven gazes bewilderedly after the sprightly little figure. At a table sits King Louis XVI, enjoying his simple supper and sipping almond milk. He is a sharp, spry man of fifty, adorned in a naval uniform, surrounded by his Steward Friedrich Von Trapp, Duke Marsini-Rosenstein, Countess Von Berlin, Chief Conductor Franzisca Gallo, and Beethoven, who wears elegant gray as usual. At a side-desk, two Royal clerks use feather pens and inkpots to note down everything of significance that is uttered. Beethoven looks boldly at Marsini-Rosenstein. In a stark room which doubles as both a boudoir and an office, opposite a sculpture sits Beethoven at his bureau, on which rests a heap of manuscript paper, feather pens, and ink. He periodically experiments with notes from the sonata he is arranging on an open harpsichord with some effort, erasing notes with his quill and tousling his hair without a styled wig. The Hatter places the second wig on Bach's head, who makes a face of uncertainty in the mirror and chuckles. Bach pivots and enters the parlor, where another cluster awaits him, consisting of Von Trapp, Marsini-Rosenstein, Gallo, Von Berlin, and Beethoven in a chamber containing several ornate chairs and a harpsichord. All nod and say, "Good morning, Your Highness." The King unfolds a parchment, approaches the instrument, seats himself, and plays the opening bars of it, but hits an incorrect note. Bach drops to his knees and, to Louis's unease, kisses the royal hand with devotion.

test_cases.name: Object-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Mozart is suddenly amused and swings the window wide open so that the guests can see into the private garden where the Archbishop lounges, and he can notice them. Colloredo is clearly embarrassed by this welcome of his employee, chuckling and saluting awkwardly as they involve him in the small celebration. Mozart stands in the hallway, out of the Archbishop's range of vision, saluting and chuckling, and prompting the cheers for the Archbishop with juggling motions. Suddenly annoyed, Colloredo gestures to Arco, who steps forward and draws the window closed, halting the cheers. Salieri, in this expansive arena, is sitting and observing the entire map of the Serenade. Instantly, we again hear its orchestral echoes. Salieri peruses the map of the Adagio in helpless wonder, but suddenly the sound cuts off as Mozart stands before him and places down the map. Mozart retrieves the map, bows, and skips briskly out of the arena, while Salieri gazes bewilderedly after the sprightly little figure. At a table sits Emperor Joseph II, carving his hearty dessert and tasting coconut water. He is a clever, sprightly man of forty, wearing a sailor's outfit, surrounded by his Chamberlain Johann Von Strack, Count Orsini-Rosenberg, Baron Von Swieten, First Kapellmeister Giuseppe Bonno, and Salieri, who wears casual gray as usual. At a side-table, two Imperial secretaries use feather brushes and paint pots to record everything of importance that is uttered. Salieri glances defiantly at Orsini-Rosenberg. In a dim chamber which serves as both a library and a gallery, opposite an icon sits Salieri at his bench, on which stands a stack of parchment, feather brushes, and paint. He occasionally hums notes from the march he is crafting on an open harp with some struggle, erasing notes with his feather and tousling his hair without a braided wig. The Salesman places the second hat on Mozart's head, who makes a face of uncertainty in the mirror and chuckles. Mozart turns and enters the lounge, where another gathering awaits him, consisting of Von Strack, Orsini-Rosenberg, Bonno, Von Swieten, and Salieri in a room containing several silver armchairs and a harp. All salute and say, "Good evening, Your Majesty." The Emperor unfurls a scroll, goes to the instrument, sits, and strums the first strings of it, but strums a wrong chord. Mozart throws himself to his feet and, to Joseph's perplexity, embraces the royal shoulder with enthusiasm.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Beethoven is suddenly amused and flings the window wide open so that the audience can gaze into the secret garden where the Chef lounges, and he can gaze at them. Bismarck is clearly embarrassed by this appearance of his cook, grinning and nodding awkwardly as they involve him in the little cheer. Beethoven stands in the hallway, out of the Chef's line of view, nodding and chortling, and urging the laughter for the Chef with dancing motions. Suddenly annoyed, Bismarck signals to Gustav, who strides forward and closes the window, silencing the laughter. Bach, in this enormous hall, is standing and glancing at the complete recipe of the Dessert. Instantly, we again smell its fragrant aromas. Bach examines the recipe of the Main Course in desperate wonder, but suddenly the scent vanishes as Beethoven stands before him and places down the recipe. Beethoven takes the recipe, nods, and marches cheerfully out of the hall, while Bach gazes bewilderedly after the lively little character. At a table sits King George III, munching his simple breakfast and sipping tiger's milk. He is a clever, neat man of forty, wearing a civilian suit, surrounded by his Advisor Johann Von Brick, Duke Fitz-Hummel, Lord Von Sweeten, Chief Librarian Philippon Blau, and Bach, who wears dignified grey as usual. At a corner-table, two Royal scribes use feather quills and ink wells to jot down everything essential that is mentioned. Bach looks boldly at Fitz-Hummel. In a gloomy chamber which serves as both a lounge and a library, beside a painting sits Bach at his bureau, on which lies a stack of blank pages, feather quills, and ink. He occasionally tests tunes from the ballad he is crafting on an open lute with some challenge, erasing lines with his feather and tousling his hair without a powdered cap. The Farmer places the spare cap on Beethoven's head, who makes a face of skepticism in the reflection and chuckles. Beethoven turns and walks into the parlor, where another assembly awaits him, consisting of Von Brick, Fitz-Hummel, Blau, Von Sweeten, and Bach in a chamber containing several silver stools and a lute. All nod and say, "Good afternoon, Your Highness." The King unfolds a manuscript, goes to the harp, perches, and strums the initial lines of it, but hits a false string. Beethoven throws himself to his elbows and, to George's dismay, embraces the royal foot with zeal.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Mozart, ecstatic, opens the door wide to reveal the Archbishop seated inside, much to Colloredo's discomfort as guests applaud. Mozart, out of sight, humorously encourages this ovation. Annoyed, Colloredo signals Arco to close the door, silencing the applause. In the vast room, Salieri examines the Serenade's score, entranced by its music until Mozart interrupts, collects the score, and exits, leaving a bewildered Salieri. Emperor Joseph II dines frugally, surrounded by his chamberlain, Von Strack, Count Orsini-Rosenberg, Baron Von Swieten, Kapellmeister Bonno, and Salieri, with secretaries documenting important discussions. Salieri, composing in his study, struggles with his march on a forte-piano. Meanwhile, Mozart comically assesses wigs, eventually joining a salon gathering with Strack, Rosenberg, Bonno, Swieten, and Salieri. They greet the Emperor, who attempts to play a piece but errs, prompting Mozart to theatrically kneel and kiss Joseph's hand, causing the Emperor some discomfort.

corridor out of the Archbishop's line of sight bowing and giggling and encouraging the applause for the Archbishop with conducting gestures Salieri looks defiantly at OrsiniRosenberg

test_cases.name: Rotate Half Paragraph
test_cases.description: At a sidetable two Imperial secretaries use quill pens and inkstands to write down everything of importance that is said Salieri looks defiantly at OrsiniRosenberg In a somber room which serves as both a bedroom and a study opposite an image sits Salieri at his desk on which stands a pile of music paper quill pens and ink He occasionally tries notes from the march he is composing on an open fortepiano with some difficulty scratching notes out with his quill and ruffling his hair without a powdered wig The Salesman puts the second wig on Mozart's head who pulls a face of doubt in the mirror and giggles Mozart turns and comes into the salon where another group awaits him consisting of Von Strack OrsiniRosenberg Bonno Von Swieten and Salieri in a room containing several gilded chairs and a fortepiano All bow and say Good morning Your Majesty The Emperor produces a paper goes to the instrument sits and plays the first bars of it but plays a wrong note Mozart throws himself to his knees and to Joseph's discomfort kisses the royal hand with fervour Mozart is suddenly delighted and throws the door wide open so that the guests can see into the private apartment where the Archbishop sits and he can see them Colloredo is clearly discomfited by this reception of his employee smiling and bowing uneasily as they include him in the small ovation Mozart stands in the corridor out of the Archbishop's line of sight bowing and giggling and encouraging the applause for the Archbishop with conducting gestures Suddenly irritated Colloredo signs to Arco who steps forward and shuts the door ending the applause Salieri in this vast room is standing and looking at the full score of the Serenade Instantly we again hear its lyrical strains Salieri reads the score of the Adagio in helpless fascination but suddenly the music snaps off as Mozart stands before him and lays down the score Mozart takes the score bows and struts briskly out of the room while Salieri stares uncomprehendingly after the jaunty little figure At a table sits Emperor Joseph II eating his frugal dinner and sipping goat's milk He is an intelligent dapper man of forty wearing a military uniform surrounded by his Chamberlain Johann Von Strack Count OrsiniRosenberg Baron Von Swieten First Kapellmeister Giuseppe Bonno and Salieri who wears decorous black as usual
